title: Psalms Chapter 110 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 110 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 110 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 110.

questions.question: Who said, 'Sit thou at my right hand, until I make thine enemies thy footstool'?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:1 states that the LORD said unto my Lord to sit at His right hand.

questions.question: From where shall the LORD send the rod of strength?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:2 says the LORD shall send the rod of thy strength out of Zion.

questions.question: According to Psalms 110:3, when shall thy people be willing?
options: In the day of thy power
questions.correctAnswer: In the day of thy power
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:3 mentions that thy people shall be willing in the day of thy power.

questions.question: What has the LORD sworn according to Psalms 110:4?
options: Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchizedek
Thou shalt reign over the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchizedek
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:4 clearly states the LORD has sworn that the subject is a priest forever after the order of Melchizedek.

questions.question: Who shall strike through kings in the day of his wrath?
options: The Lord at thy right hand
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord at thy right hand
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:5 says the Lord at thy right hand shall strike through kings in the day of his wrath.

questions.question: What will he do among the heathen, according to Psalms 110:6?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:6 states he shall judge among the heathen.

questions.question: What shall he fill the places with, as mentioned in Psalms 110:6?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:6 mentions he shall fill the places with dead bodies.

questions.question: What shall he wound over many countries?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:6 says he shall wound the heads over many countries.

questions.question: What shall he drink of in the way, according to Psalms 110:7?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:7 states he shall drink of the brook in the way.

questions.question: Why shall he lift up the head, according to Psalms 110:7?
options: Because he drank of the brook in the way
Because he was blessed by the LORD
Because he ruled over many nations
questions.correctAnswer: Because he drank of the brook in the way
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:7 explains he shall lift up the head because he drank of the brook in the way.

questions.question: Who is the Psalm of, as stated in Psalms 110:1?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:1 identifies this Psalm as a Psalm of David.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 110:4 states the LORD will repent of His oath.
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:4 clearly says the LORD hath sworn and will not repent.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 110:2 commands to rule in the midst of thine enemies.
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:2 says, 'rule thou in the midst of thine enemies.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 110:3 mentions the people shall be unwilling in the day of thy power.
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:3 states thy people shall be willing, not unwilling.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 110:1: 'The LORD said unto my Lord, Sit thou at my ______ hand, until I make thine enemies thy footstool.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:1 states 'Sit thou at my right hand.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 110 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 110 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 110, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God's power in difficult times?
options: God will make your enemies your footstool and give you strength to overcome
You must rely solely on your own strength to defeat challenges
God will remove all problems immediately without any effort from you
Your enemies will never be defeated, so you should avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: God will make your enemies your footstool and give you strength to overcome
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:1 and 110:2 show that the LORD promises strength and victory over enemies, teaching us to trust His power and timing in trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 110:3 encourage believers to respond in times of spiritual responsibility and leadership?
options: To be willing and joyful in serving God with youthful energy and holiness
To lead by force and intimidation
To focus only on personal success without concern for holiness
To avoid responsibility and wait passively
questions.correctAnswer: To be willing and joyful in serving God with youthful energy and holiness
questions.explanation: Verse 3 highlights the willingness of God's people in the day of power and the beauty of holiness, encouraging believers to serve joyfully and faithfully.

questions.question: What biblical principle about spiritual authority and service can we learn from Psalms 110:4?
options: Jesus is a priest forever in the order of Melchizedek, showing eternal spiritual authority
Priests serve only for a limited time
Spiritual authority is temporary and based on human appointment
No one can be a priest forever
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus is a priest forever in the order of Melchizedek, showing eternal spiritual authority
questions.explanation: Verse 4 teaches about the eternal priesthood according to Melchizedek’s order, emphasizing the lasting spiritual authority and intercession of Christ.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with anger towards others. Based on Psalms 110, what truth about God’s judgment and justice would you share?
options: God will judge among the nations and execute justice in His timing
God ignores injustice and lets it continue
Justice is not important in spiritual life
questions.correctAnswer: God will judge among the nations and execute justice in His timing
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:5-6 show that the Lord executes judgment on the heathen and brings justice, teaching patience and trust in God’s righteous judgment.

questions.question: How does Psalms 110:7 inspire believers to persist through spiritual dryness or exhaustion?
options: Even when weary, God provides refreshment and strength to lift up your head
You should give up when tired because God will not help
Spiritual dryness means God has abandoned you
Rest is unnecessary in spiritual life
questions.correctAnswer: Even when weary, God provides refreshment and strength to lift up your head
questions.explanation: Verse 7 illustrates that despite hardships, God’s provision (like drinking from a brook) sustains us and enables perseverance.

questions.question: In Psalms 110:2, what does the 'rod of thy strength' symbolize for believers facing opposition at work or in community service?
options: God’s power and authority to rule and prevail even among enemies
A literal weapon to fight physically
Avoidance of all conflict at any cost
questions.correctAnswer: God’s power and authority to rule and prevail even among enemies
questions.explanation: The 'rod of thy strength' in verse 2 symbolizes God’s empowering presence enabling believers to lead and overcome opposition.

questions.question: How can Psalms 110:1 teach us about humility and contentment in our spiritual walk?
options: We are called to sit at God’s right hand in submission and trust His plan
We should demand immediate recognition and power
Contentment means never striving for growth
Humility is unnecessary if you are strong
questions.correctAnswer: We are called to sit at God’s right hand in submission and trust His plan
questions.explanation: Verse 1 shows the posture of sitting at God's right hand, implying trust and humility in waiting on His timing and authority.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 110 teaches that God’s promises to His people are unchanging and sure.
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:4 says the LORD hath sworn and will not repent, confirming the certainty of God’s promises.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 110, believers should rely on their own strength rather than God’s power to overcome enemies.
questions.explanation: Verses 1 and 2 emphasize God sending strength and ruling in the midst of enemies, teaching reliance on God’s power rather than our own.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 110:3 says, 'Thy people shall be willing in the day of thy power, in the beauties of _____.'
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states that the people shall be willing in the day of power, 'in the beauties of holiness,' emphasizing the importance of holy living.

questions.question: How does Psalms 110:5 encourage believers to maintain integrity and courage in their leadership roles?
options: The Lord at your right hand will strike through enemies, empowering righteous leadership
Leadership depends only on human skill and manipulation
Avoid standing up for righteousness to keep peace
Power in leadership is gained through deceit
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord at your right hand will strike through enemies, empowering righteous leadership
questions.explanation: Verse 5 shows that God’s presence empowers and protects leaders who act justly, encouraging integrity and courage.

questions.question: What does Psalms 110:6 teach about God’s role in reconciliation and justice among nations?
options: God judges among the heathen and executes justice, showing His commitment to righteousness
God ignores conflicts and injustice between nations
Humans alone decide justice without God’s involvement
Reconciliation is impossible in this world
questions.correctAnswer: God judges among the heathen and executes justice, showing His commitment to righteousness
questions.explanation: Verse 6 describes God’s judgment and justice among the nations, reminding believers to trust His righteous governance.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged in prayer and service. Based on Psalms 110, what encouragement can you offer about God’s sustaining power?
options: God provides refreshment and strength, like drinking from a brook, enabling you to lift your head
You must serve only when you feel strong and refreshed
Spiritual service is optional and not important
Prayer is unnecessary when feeling weak
questions.correctAnswer: God provides refreshment and strength, like drinking from a brook, enabling you to lift your head
questions.explanation: Verse 7 illustrates God’s sustaining care, providing refreshment and strength during weariness to continue faithfully.

questions.question: How does Psalms 110 model the importance of faith and obedience in family and church leadership?
options: By showing willing people in holiness under God’s authority, emphasizing faithful service
By teaching to ignore God’s commands in leadership
By promoting selfish ambition over service
By discouraging commitment to spiritual responsibilities
questions.correctAnswer: By showing willing people in holiness under God’s authority, emphasizing faithful service
questions.explanation: Verses 2 and 3 show God’s people willingly serving in holiness and under His authority, which is key to faithful family and church leadership.

questions.question: What does Psalms 110 teach about perseverance through trials and trusting God’s timing for victory?
options: Believers must wait patiently as God makes enemies their footstool and provides strength
Victory always comes immediately without waiting
Trials mean God has forsaken you
You should rely on yourself and not wait on God
questions.correctAnswer: Believers must wait patiently as God makes enemies their footstool and provides strength
questions.explanation: Verse 1 encourages patience and trust in God’s timing for victory, teaching perseverance through trials.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 110 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 110.

questions.question: In Psalms 110:1, who is referred to as 'my Lord' to whom the LORD says, 'Sit thou at my right hand'?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:1 uses a messianic title 'my Lord' indicating a figure greater than David, traditionally understood as the Messiah who sits at God's right hand.

questions.question: What is the symbolic meaning of 'enemies being made thy footstool' in Psalms 110:1?
questions.explanation: The phrase 'enemies thy footstool' in Psalms 110:1 symbolizes total victory and dominance over adversaries, a common Near Eastern royal metaphor.

questions.question: According to Psalms 110:2, from which place will the LORD send the 'rod of thy strength'?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:2 explicitly states that the LORD will send the 'rod of thy strength' out of Zion, emphasizing Zion's centrality as God's holy place.

questions.question: In Psalms 110:3, the phrase 'dew of thy youth' is a metaphor for what?
questions.explanation: The 'dew of thy youth' in Psalms 110:3 poetically represents freshness and vitality, akin to the rejuvenating dew in the early morning.

questions.question: Psalms 110:4 declares that the LORD has sworn an oath concerning the priesthood of the subject. This priesthood is said to be after the order of whom?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:4 explicitly identifies the priestly order as 'after the order of Melchizedek,' a figure who combines kingship and priesthood.

questions.question: What is the significance of Melchizedek’s priesthood in Psalms 110:4 in relation to the Levitical priesthood?
options: It predates and surpasses the Levitical priesthood
It is identical to the Levitical priesthood
It applies only to the tribe of Levi
It was limited to the Tabernacle
questions.correctAnswer: It predates and surpasses the Levitical priesthood
questions.explanation: Melchizedek’s priesthood in Psalms 110:4 is understood as eternal and superior, predating and surpassing the Levitical priesthood, foreshadowing Christ's eternal priesthood.

questions.question: In Psalms 110:5, who is depicted as striking through kings in the day of wrath?
options: The LORD at thy right hand
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD at thy right hand
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:5 clearly states that 'The Lord at thy right hand shall strike through kings,' indicating divine power acting through the Messiah.

questions.question: Which literary device is most prominent in Psalms 110:6, where it says 'He shall fill the places with the dead bodies; he shall wound the heads over many countries'?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:6 uses hyperbolic language to emphasize the overwhelming victory and judgment executed by the Messiah.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 110:7 suggests that after victorious battle, the subject will find refreshment and thus lift up his head.
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:7 describes the victorious figure drinking from the brook and lifting up his head, symbolizing refreshment and triumph.

questions.question: The phrase 'Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchizedek' in Psalms 110:4 is most explicitly referenced in which New Testament book?
questions.explanation: The author of Hebrews extensively discusses Melchizedek’s priesthood as eternal and superior in chapters 5–7, directly citing Psalms 110:4.

questions.question: What is the cultural significance of the 'rod of thy strength' mentioned in Psalms 110:2 in the ancient Near East?
options: A symbol of kingship and authority
questions.correctAnswer: A symbol of kingship and authority
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, a rod or staff often symbolized royal authority and power, as reflected in Psalms 110:2.

questions.question: In Psalms 110:3, the phrase 'in the beauties of holiness from the womb of the morning' employs which poetic device?
questions.explanation: The phrase metaphorically describes the fresh, holy enthusiasm of the people at the start of the day, highlighting spiritual vitality.

questions.question: How does Psalms 110:1 foreshadow the New Testament theme of Jesus' heavenly exaltation?
options: By depicting a king seated at God's right hand
By describing the building of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: By depicting a king seated at God's right hand
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:1's imagery of a king seated at God's right hand is used in the New Testament to describe Jesus’ exaltation (e.g., Acts 2:34-35).

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 110 is developed across Scripture as both kingly and priestly roles combined in one figure?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110 presents a unique fusion of kingly and priestly roles, fulfilled in the Messiah, a theme developed in both the Old and New Testaments.

questions.question: The phrase 'He shall judge among the heathen' in Psalms 110:6 reflects what broader biblical motif?
options: The giving of the Ten Commandments
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:6 emphasizes the Messiah's role in executing God's judgment universally, a motif echoed throughout biblical prophecy.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 110 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 110 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 110:1, who does the LORD say should sit at His right hand until His enemies are made a footstool?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:1 states, 'The LORD said unto my Lord, Sit thou at my right hand, until I make thine enemies thy footstool.' This indicates a divine conversation where God addresses 'My Lord' to sit at His right hand, a position of authority. This is echoed in Matthew 22:44 and Hebrews 1:13 where Jesus is identified as 'My Lord.'

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'right hand' in Psalms 110:1 and 110:5?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:1 and 110:5 refer to sitting or standing at the right hand, symbolizing authority and power. In Acts 7:55-56 and Mark 16:19, Jesus is described as sitting at the right hand of God, confirming this position as one of divine honor.

questions.question: In Psalms 110:2, what does the 'rod of thy strength' symbolize?
options: Divine authority and power to rule
questions.correctAnswer: Divine authority and power to rule
questions.explanation: The 'rod of thy strength' in Psalms 110:2 symbolizes the authority and power given by God to rule over enemies. This is consistent with Hebrews 1:8 and Revelation 2:27, where the Messiah is given a rod to rule the nations with justice.

questions.question: Who is described as a priest forever according to the order of Melchizedek in Psalms 110:4?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:4 refers to a priest forever after the order of Melchizedek. Hebrews 7:17-21 clarifies that Jesus is this eternal priest, distinct from the Levitical priesthood, fulfilling the priesthood in an eternal and perfect way.

questions.question: What promise does God make in Psalms 110:4 regarding His oath?
options: He will appoint a temporary priest
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:4 states that the LORD hath sworn and will not repent regarding the priesthood after Melchizedek’s order. This unchangeable oath is affirmed in Hebrews 6:17-18, signifying God's faithfulness and the certainty of Christ's eternal priesthood.

questions.question: According to Psalms 110:3, what characterizes 'thy people' in the day of power?
options: They shall be willing and adorned in holiness
They shall be fearful and rebellious
They shall be silent and hidden
They shall be scattered and lost
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be willing and adorned in holiness
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:3 describes 'thy people' as willing in the day of power and adorned with the beauties of holiness, symbolizing a willing and sanctified community. This aligns with 2 Corinthians 6:1 and 1 Peter 1:15-16 where believers are called to holiness and readiness.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'thou hast the dew of thy youth' in Psalms 110:3 symbolize?
questions.explanation: The phrase 'dew of thy youth' in Psalms 110:3 symbolizes freshness, vigor, and vitality. This poetic imagery is consistent with Isaiah 40:31 and Proverbs 3:18, which use dew and youth to represent renewed strength and flourishing life.

questions.question: In Psalms 110:5-6, what actions are described that the LORD at the right hand will perform?
options: Strike through kings and judge among heathen
Bless the meek and comfort the poor
questions.correctAnswer: Strike through kings and judge among heathen
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:5-6 describes the Lord at the right hand striking kings and judging among the heathen, emphasizing divine judgment and victory over enemies. This is consistent with Revelation 19:15 and Isaiah 66:16, where the Messiah judges and executes justice.

questions.question: What does the imagery of 'wound the heads over many countries' in Psalms 110:6 convey?
questions.explanation: The phrase 'wound the heads over many countries' in Psalms 110:6 symbolizes the defeat of rulers and authorities, reflecting the Messiah’s sovereign rule. This aligns with Colossians 2:15 and Daniel 7:14, which describe Christ’s triumph over earthly powers.

questions.question: What is the meaning of 'He shall drink of the brook in the way' in Psalms 110:7?
options: He shall find refreshment and strength during his journey
He shall be thirsty and weak
He shall avoid water and hardship
He shall be judged by the nations
questions.correctAnswer: He shall find refreshment and strength during his journey
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:7’s phrase indicates that the Messiah will receive sustenance and refreshment during his mission, implying divine provision. This is consistent with Isaiah 58:11 and John 4:14, where living water symbolizes spiritual refreshment and strength.

questions.question: What is the significance of the enemies being made 'thy footstool' in Psalms 110:1?
options: Complete subjugation and authority over enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Complete subjugation and authority over enemies
questions.explanation: Making enemies a 'footstool' in Psalms 110:1 symbolizes total victory and dominion over adversaries, a theme found in 1 Corinthians 15:25 and Ephesians 1:22, where Christ is given authority over all enemies and powers.

questions.question: How does Psalms 110:4 contribute to understanding the uniqueness of Christ’s priesthood?
options: It is eternal and after the order of Melchizedek
questions.correctAnswer: It is eternal and after the order of Melchizedek
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:4 emphasizes the eternal nature of the priesthood after Melchizedek’s order, contrasting with the temporary Levitical priesthood. Hebrews 7:3 and Hebrews 7:23-28 affirm this uniqueness, highlighting Christ’s eternal intercession.

questions.question: What theological theme is most clearly expressed in Psalms 110:2 regarding the Messiah's reign?
options: Messianic kingship and victorious rule amidst opposition
questions.correctAnswer: Messianic kingship and victorious rule amidst opposition
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:2 portrays the Messiah ruling in the midst of enemies with strength, highlighting the theme of victorious Messianic kingship. This is consistent with Revelation 19:11-16 and Daniel 7:13-14, where Christ reigns supreme over all opposition.

questions.question: In Psalms 110:5-6, what role does the LORD at the right hand perform in eschatological judgment?
options: Executing wrath and judgment over nations
questions.correctAnswer: Executing wrath and judgment over nations
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 depict the LORD at the right hand executing wrath and judging nations, a key eschatological role. This aligns with Revelation 20:11-15 and Psalm 9:7-8, where God is the righteous judge at the end of days.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'therefore shall he lift up the head' in Psalms 110:7 signify about the Messiah's status?
questions.explanation: Psalms 110:7 concludes with the lifting up of the head, symbolizing triumph and exaltation after victory. This is echoed in Isaiah 52:13 and Luke 24:26, where the Messiah is exalted following suffering and victory.
